case_004_generated.wav:
Sara’s uncle, Mo, recently passed away in his hometown of San Clemente, CA. The only estate planning document found in Mo’s possession was a Will signed on July 28, 2022. The Will names Sara as the Personal Representative of Mo’s estate. Sara hires Julia, a T&E attorney, as counsel to help probate the estate. It turns out that Mo only owned two assets: (i) a primary residence valued at $22MM subject to a $8MM mortgage, and (ii) a savings account with a value of $9MM. Both assets were titled only in Mo’s name and are subject to probate.
- Under California law, what is the amount of the Personal Representative’s Fees that will be paid to Sara for her services as PR of Mo’s estate?
- Under California law, what is the amount of the Attorney’s Fees that will be paid to Julia for her legal services?
- How could Mo have avoided these fees?
- What is a best practice that analysts can perform to make sure this doesn’t happen to ABC PB clients?

case_067_generated.wav:
These are the instructions I received for a task. Give me some examples of Estate Planning slides that I can edit in order to better fit this description:

What we are trying to show is Washington estate taxes. These were updated on May 20th to be more drastic at the state level (shown in the chart below), but the Federal rate has remained the same. We are trying to show these changes and the impact it will have on our clients who live in Washington.

Some things I would like to show on the slides are:

Previous versus new rates. See below of the numbers. Feel free to paste a version of this into the PowerPoint.

There are two Excel calculators attached above—one for an individual’s estate taxes and one for a married couple. I would like to put these into client friendly format in the PowerPoint. Maybe do 1 slide each for individual and married. Make sure to include the Assumptions section.

Taxable Amount / Previous Incremental Rate / New Incremental Rate / New Tax Owed

$0 to $1,000,000 → 10% of taxable amount → 10% of taxable amount

$1,000,000 to $2,000,000 → 14% of the amount over $1,000,000 plus $100,000 → 15% of the amount over $1,000,000 plus $100,000

$2,000,000 to $3,000,000 → 15% of the amount over $2,000,000 plus $240,000 → 20% of the amount over $2,000,000 plus $250,000

$3,000,000 to $4,000,000 → 16% of the amount over $3,000,000 plus $390,000 → 21% of the amount over $3,000,000 plus $450,000

$4,000,000 to $6,000,000 → 18% of the amount over $4,000,000 plus $550,000 → 22% of the amount over $4,000,000 plus $720,000

$6,000,000 to $7,000,000 → 19% of the amount over $6,000,000 plus $910,000 → 24% of the amount over $6,000,000 plus $1,140,000

$7,000,000 to $9,000,000 → 19.5% of the amount over $7,000,000 plus $1,100,000 → 26% of the amount over $7,000,000 plus $1,390,000

$9,000,000 and above → 20% of the amount over $9,000,000 plus $1,490,000 → 28% of the amount over $9,000,000 plus $1,910,000

My client earns above $20,000,000 plus 75% of that is inherited (as an example), and her son receives $15,000,000 and her daughter receives $5,000,000.
case_068_generated.wav:
My client wants to split her assets so that her husband receives 25% and her son receives 75%. Currently, she has an individual account with a balance amount of $822,000. Her other accounts are as follows:

C93230306 MARY M MOON IRA Beneficiaries:

33% to CHARLES ALAN JEFFERSON (spouse)

67% to ALEXANDER MOON (son)

C81278001 MARY M MOON IN IRA Beneficiaries:

34% to CHARLES ALAN JEFFERSON (spouse)

66% to ALEXANDER MOON (son)

Please suggest the best way to divide the assets to accomplish her goal knowing that the individual account gets a step up in basis and taking into account the tax implications of the IRA accounts.
case_069_generated.wav:
I’m writing an email to a US-based C-Suite executive of a UK-based company. I am not sure if they have elected QSBS for their shares or eligible (or if they even get them). What would you add or subtract from the below list of items I’m telling them to consider / what’s important to them remains private, some items to contemplate include:
- Tracking what’s vested or exercised in terms of shares/options 
- Considering strategies to maximize your tax savings if you can exercise unvested equity stakes early 
- Structuring assets efficiently to minimize income and estate taxes 
- Weighing the risks and benefits of an 83(b) election 
- Preparing your personal balance sheet for a future liquidity event 
- Thinking about a 10b5-1 plan for diversification post-IPO
